block.p: New Questions Raised On Gulf War Attack New questions have emerged about the conduct of one of the top American commanders in the Persian Gulf war who came under investigation in 1991 after a member of his unit complained that his troops had pummeled retreating Iraqi forces in an unprovoked attack.

Palestinians Protest in Israel Thousands of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza poured into the streets for angry protests, some of which were marked by violent confrontations with Israeli troops. The protesters called for Israel to release Palestinian prisoners. In a prison in northern Israel, the prisoners themselves rioted.

Concerns Over Peru's Election International observers say they have serious concerns that President Alberto K. Fujimori may be preparing to steal enough votes to ensure he wins a third term. The concerns are so grave that Mr. Fujimori's challenger is threatening to pull out of the race rather than lend credibility to a process he sees as flawed.

Important Vote in Germany The governing Social Democrats won a comfortable victory in Germany's largest state, North Rhine-Westphalia, confirming both the resurgence of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and the plight of the opposition Christian Democrats.

European Federation Proposed Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, has proposed the creation of a European federation in which power would shift from national governments to a central European administration.

Some U.N. Troops Are Freed Eighteen of the United Nations peacekeepers held hostage by rebel forces in Sierra Leone since the beginning of the month were released over the weekend after negotiations between Indian peacekeepers and local rebels.

More Ethiopia-Eritrea Fighting Ethiopia said that it had captured more ground in a third day of clashes with its neighbor, Eritrea, but Eritrean officials said the report was just propaganda aimed at voters in Ethiopia's nationwide elections.

Search for Bodies in Kosovo Teams from the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague have resumed their search in Kosovo for bodies and other clues that would back the indictment of the Yugoslav president and four of his top allies on war crimes charges.

Belgrade Presses Opponents The Yugoslav government announced a crackdown on the country's main opposition groups, accusing them of masterminding, on behalf of NATO, the slaying of Bosko Perosevic, a top official in the governing Socialist Party. The groups have denied the accusations.

Hundreds of Thousands March for Gun Control Mothers and other gun control advocates marched on the nation's capital and in several cities around the country, demanding ''sensible gun laws'' and vowing to transform the politics of gun control.

Gore Camp Seeks Focus Vice President Al Gore's campaign is struggling to reorient itself toward the general election and many of Mr. Gore's closest advisers concede that Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has outmaneuvered them in appealing to moderate voters.
Some women in Chicago who said they normally voted Democratic expressed dissatisfaction with Mr. Gore, echoing reactions that have been suggested on a larger scale in recent national polls.

Elderly Fight for Coverage In the struggle over how to strengthen Medicare, elderly people seeking prescription drug benefits have found themselves competing against hospitals and other health care providers that want Congress to increase payments to them.

More Oversight in Los Angeles The Justice Department's announcement last week that it was prepared to file a civil rights lawsuit against the Los Angeles Police Department was only the latest in a series of federal actions and oversight efforts that have made greater Los Angeles a virtual ward of Washington.

Los Alamos Fire Spreads The fire at Los Alamos, N.M., that has destroyed more than 42,000 acres continued to expand. But the area's emotional recovery began as the New Mexico National Guard organized bus tours for residents whose homes had been destroyed.
Gore Jokes Aren't Gore's The Jewish jokes that Vice President Al Gore used last week turn out to have come from a Web site, which was not credited as the source.

Assigning Worth to Genes Genetic testing is becoming more common, and, for almost every gene, some medical institution or some company owns a patent on its use. But patients whose cells provided the genes that have been patented are almost never compensated. Now, some patients have become wary about providing their tissue for genetic research. A few have demanded money up front before providing tissue. Others are writing contracts spelling out what they are entitled to if they help scientists find genes.

Conflicting Advice As Giuliani Weighs Choices Mayor Giuliani found himself confronting an array of conflicting advice from a divided group of advisers, as he neared a final decision about the future of his campaign for the United States Senate. Some of the advisers have financial, political and career interests riding on whether Mr. Giuliani pursues his campaign against Hillary Rodham Clinton.
New York State Republican Party leaders are quietly moving ahead with efforts to identify possible replacement candidates for Mayor Giuliani.

Pataki Ads Criticized Governor Pataki has starred in no fewer than five television advertising campaigns paid for by state agencies under his control. The advertisements have led government reform groups and Democrats to charge that they are nothing more than a veiled political campaign at government expense.

Suit Against Con Edison Westchester County plans to file a lawsuit today seeking to stop Consolidated Edison from increasing electric bills to cover costs from a radioactive leak at a nuclear plant in February, the county executive said.

Cabby Stabbed to Death A yellow-cab driver died in Manhattan after another driver stabbed him twice in the chest during an argument over a parking space, the police said. The stabbing was one of six killings in the city in 24 hours.
Knicks Defeat the Heat The Knicks defeated the Heat, 91-83, evening their Eastern Conference semifinal series at two games apiece.
Keizo Obuchi A bland, self-effacing politician who as Japan's prime minister brought some stability to the country's faltering economy and fractious politics, he was 62.

Margaret Harris A theatrical designer whose name was synonymous for more than half a century with superlative yet economical stage sets and costumes in London, Stratford-Upon-Avon and on Broadway, she was 95.

Fed to Meet on Interest Rates The Federal Reserve Board meets tomorrow to consider whether to raise interest rates and, amid signs of inflation, may feel compelled to adopt a more aggressive inflation-fighting stance than it has employed in years. Analysts and investors expect the central bank to raise its benchmark interest rate by a half-percentage point at the meeting.

Deal for 'Friends' Stars The stars of the NBC comedy ''Friends'' agreed to a deal that would bring the show back for two more seasons, and would pay them each $750,000 an episode as well as a higher percentage of future profits from the show's sales in syndication. The six stars had demanded more than $1 million an episode.

A.I.G. Board Challenged Several shareholder proposals challenging the dominance of the chief executive of the American International Group will be presented at the annual meeting on Wednesday. Experts say the demands highlight the gap between A.I.G.'s management structure and prevailing practices at most American corporations.
Intel Plans Spinoff Intel plans to announce today that it will spin off a tiny Internet company, Developonline.com, that it hopes will help consumers and business custom-order technology products.

Berkshire Earnings Rise In its quarterly report, released on the Internet on Saturday, Berkshire Hathaway posted net income of $807 million, or $531 a Class A share, compared with $541 million, or $356 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue increased 18.8 percent, to $6.47 billion from $5.44 billion.

Metal Companies to Go Online Fourteen of the world's largest mining and metals companies said that they were creating a single procurement marketplace on the Internet, which could cut the industry's $200 billion-a-year supply bill.
